definition.description: How can we redesign a product's packaging to make it more environmentally friendly?
definition.summary: Product packaging often uses materials and processes that negatively affect the Earth. In your role as design engineers, use the engineering-design process and geometric modeling to redesign a product's packaging to render it more sustainable. Explore volume, surface area, and dimensions of complex shapes to develop prototypes that meet the product's packaging design constraints while limiting the packaging material used and/or waste generated.

outcomes.description: Packaging prototype with detailed annotated drawings that show geometric modeling.
Video or in-person pitch of a packaging prototype.
Share packaging prototype with a retailer or manufacturer

milestones.subject: How does the packaging we use affect the planet?
milestones.description: Students explore the impact of packaging waste on the environment.

support-items.subject: Have students document and reflect on all of the disposable packaging they use in their daily lives.
support-items.description: In the week leading up to the project launch, challenge students to take photos of every disposable package their family opens or uses for 1 week, which might include boxes used for shipping as well as food containers, plastic wrappers, and other materials. (Have students omit packaging of sensitive or personal products such as medical supplies.) On the day of the project launch, have students share the photos of their packaging in a class slideshow. As you share the slideshow with students, have students consider the implications of this packaging for the environment: where does it all go? Facilitate a See Think Wonder routine about the packaging images.

Form project teams and have teams select products to repackage.
support-items.description: Create student teams of three to four. For support in this process see the Forming Teams and Using Roles in Teams strategy guides. Have each team review the sample packaging the class collected, and choose one product for which they wish to design improved packaging, for example, eggs, pizza, toothpaste, shampoo, medications, or pet food.

milestones.subject: What design criteria should we consider when developing our packaging?
milestones.description: Teams consider user interviews and sustainability guidelines to develop criteria and constraints for their package designs.

support-items.subject: Introduce the engineering design process.
support-items.description: Show students the overview video and resources from the TeachEngineering website.

support-items.subject: Have students plan for and conduct empathy interviews with potential users of their packaging.
support-items.description: Guide students to identify people who are likely to use the products for which they are designing packaging, which may include family members and friends. Have students ask questions to understand what people need and prioritize in packaging for this particular product (e.g., durability, weight, ease of opening, sanitation, cost). If possible, have students observe users as they engage with/transport/open/dispose of the current packaging

support-items.subject: Introduce key concepts related to waste reduction and sustainable packaging.
support-items.description: Have students review the Design Guidelines for Sustainable Packaging from the Sustainable Packaging Coalition (requires free login). support-items.subject: Guide students to develop a set of criteria and constraints for their packaging designs.
support-items.description: Have students work with their teams to identify what their packaging design needs to do. Have students use the data they gathered from their empathy interviews and observations, as well as their discussion of sustainable packaging guidelines, to develop and prioritize their criteria.

support-items.subject: Facilitate an individual reflection.
support-items.description: Have students respond in writing or via video reflection to the prompt: how did interviewing and observing users affect your thinking about this design challenge?

support-items.subject: Revisit the list of need-to-know questions with students.
support-items.description: Identify questions that have been answered, as well as new questions that have emerged. For more information about revisiting the need-to-know questions, see this strategy guide.

notes.subject: Support student reflection throughout this milestone with prompts such as the following: How does the engineering design process help you create designs that meet user needs? What trade-offs (e.g., cost vs. durability) do you need to consider as you prioritize criteria and constraints?

milestones.subject: How can we use geometric principles to reduce waste in packaging design?
milestones.description: Teams investigate concepts of net, surface area, and volume in relation to their packaging designs.

support-items.subject: Guide an exploration of the design optimization component of waste reduction and the geometric concepts of net, surface area, and volume.
support-items.description: Emphasize that, in addition to considering materials and disposability or durability of packaging, students can use geometric modeling to design packaging that minimizes waste and use of space while protecting products.
